text: [Music]
well Yahoo in an interesting situation
because they don't actually have uh uh
ownership of their subsidiary in China
it's run by a separate Chinese company
uh and they don't have a majority
control now I don't know I have no real
deep knowledge of what what they could
be doing in other words does their
contract allow them to withdraw the
brand and under what circumstances uh
but I mean I think some of the the main
principles people should be using is to
say um you know we're going to uh notify
people when we've censored content this
is one of the things that Google does if
you if you're in China and you search
for something um they tell you that some
of the results were removed from this
page uh so that it raises people's
awareness that gee I'm not seeing the
whole internet um another thing you can
do is try really hard to keep user data
out of China uh so that you don't end up
um you know causing political uh
activists to go to jail for complaining
about the government uh those are some
of the kinds of things that I think uh
should be done but then additionally uh
the thing that people need to remember
is that uh China is not a uh crazed
oneperson dictatorship right there are a
few of those around the planet and uh
those present very different
difficulties and obstacles China is a
country of laws there's a legisl there's
lobbyist it's not a really great
democracy in lots of ways um but it is a
place where policy can be changed uh
through uh you know lobbying processes
and uh I would like to see these
companies making an investment there um
and making the case in a really serious
way at the highest levels that um you
know this is uh this is something that
that should be changed it's not good for
China's image around the world and it's
not good internally for China I'm
hopeful right now we've just had a
change in the government in China so
there's been some shuffling of ministers
so uh we're going to have a new minister
in charge of censoring the internet uh I
have no idea what his views are going to
be but hopefully they'll be a little
more uh open and uh uh we also have the
Olympics coming up and so a lot of
people believe that the unblocking that
have occurred recently have to do with
Public Image around the Olympics uh also
Public Image around Tibet um it's an
important issue uh for China and uh uh
opening things up a bit sort of makes
people feel a little better about China
and uh that's something we lots of
people have said uh they think China is
going to try to put forward the best
face during the Olympics lots of people
are concerned too that of course as soon
as the Olympics are over it's just
Crackdown time again uh I don't know if
that's true or not I mean I I don't
think that they're that unreasonable I
think uh if what happens is Gee we we
unblocked Wikipedia even Chinese
Wikipedia for um you know six months and
what we found out was gee lots of
Chinese people went on Chinese Wikipedia
and started putting forward a Chinese
point of view instead of the Taiwanese
point of view it's not a bad thing and
actually we don't have riots in the
streets or anything it's actually pretty
dull and grand scheme of things people
are looking at Wikipedia so what uh and
then decide to leave it open uh to say
well look this isn't the kind of thing
we need to be worried about even if
we're still going to be quite harsh on
bloggers who criticize the government
and things like that well I don't know
what's going to happen we'll
